results.title: Child Care and Development
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Child care and development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Child development series”.
The film gives overall consideration to the habits of daily physical care that ensure a happy, healthy child. Correct attitudes and procedures toward establishing good habits of eating, sleeping, and bathing are covered. Stresses the elements of good diet. The question of proper clothing - warm and light for the infant, sturdy and functional for the toddler - is explored. Raises the important consideration of suitable and becoming clothing as exerting considerable psychological influence on personality development. The importance of outdoor exercise is stressed. The film shows the importance of the attitudes of both parents and children towards good routines of daily living.

results.title: Child behaviour = you
results.brief_description: Would you pick up a baby when he cries for attention, or let him yell out his little lungs? This cartoon film for parents poses many such questions that confront a mother during the course of her day. Made with the counsel of child specialists, it provides a perceptive guide to understanding what motivates both good and problem behavior in children from infancy to adolescence, and how to draw out the best.

results.title: Child abuse: emergency management
results.creator_credit: S William Hinzman, Producers Service Center and Paul McCollough
results.brief_description: A child is brought to an hospital emergency room with bruises that indicate possible abuse. This program addresses how to identify whether a crime has been committed, procedures emergency room personnel should follow upon admission of a child and how to approach the parents. The main characters are portrayed by experienced hospital staff and the program emphasises that help can be provided only if the interaction with the parents is handled with skill, support and empathy. Highlights the importance of an interdisciplinary approach to assist the family and child.

results.title: Child abuse: cradle of violence
results.creator_credit: Jerry Kingsley, Bananza Films, J. Gary Mitchell and Richard Gebhardt
results.brief_description: Through penetrating on-camera interviews with parents, many of them former abusers, the film introduces the grim reality of child abuse. Shows hopeful models for dealing with abuse problems. Also looks at positive parenting, and underlines the need for citizen reporting of suspected abuse so that the abusive family can be helped.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jerry Kingsley, Bananza Films, J. Gary Mitchell and Richard Gebhardt

results.title: Child's toy tin magic lantern with candle projection
results.credit_line: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit, Germany, c. 1900 ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description:
Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious and supernatural scenes, like sinners roasting in Purgatory and Death wielding a scythe. Luckily, magic lanterns weren’t used only by clergymen but also by a wide variety of entertainers and educators in homes, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations, scientists revealed the latest discoveries and charlatan magicians spooked audiences with dancing skeletons.

Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.

results.title: Child's play: window on development
results.creator_credit: Vision Associates and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich
results.brief_description: Shows four types of play, including social, dramatic, sensory, and skill mastery, and levels of attainment from infancy through adolescence. Narrated by Sandra Scarr-Salapatek.

results.title: Child's play and the real world (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films, Sterling Educational Films and James M. Smith
results.brief_description: Examines the intimate, colorful and whimsical world of children at play. It dispels the impression that child’s play is merely an entertaining diversion into make-believe and shows how it forms an important part in the development of expression and imagination in children.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Davidson Films, Sterling Educational Films and James M. Smith

results.title: Child's play (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows how mental, social, emotional and physical growth are linked to a child’s form of play and how these forms change as the child grows older. Illustrates how play allows children to work out their feelings and frustrations as well as providing a stage for creative ideas and fantasies.
